brief_summary.textblock:
To allow, on a compassionate use basis, zalcitabine (ddC) for pediatric patients with
      symptomatic HIV disease who have failed treatment or who are intolerant to zidovudine (AZT),
      or who have completed other ddC protocols, or who are ineligible for ongoing clinical
      trials.

clinical_study.brief_title: An Open-Label Safety Program for the Use of Zalcitabine (Dideoxycytidine; ddC) in Pediatric Patients With Symptomatic HIV Infection Who Have Failed or Are Intolerant to AZT Monotherapy, or Who Have Completed Other ddC Protocols, or Are Ineligible for Other Ongoing Clinical Studies

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients receive ddC and are evaluated at study entry and every 3 months thereafter, until 3
      months after ddC becomes approved for pediatric patients or the sponsor deems it necessary
      to terminate the protocol.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria

        Patients must have:

          -  Symptomatic HIV infection.

          -  Failure on or intolerance to AZT monotherapy OR completed other ddC protocols OR been
             ineligible for other ongoing clinical trials.

          -  Consent of parent or guardian required.

        Note:

          -  Patients who do not meet the eligibility requirements may discuss their cases with
             the medical monitor.

clinical_study.official_title: An Open-Label Safety Program for the Use of Zalcitabine (Dideoxycytidine; ddC) in Pediatric Patients With Symptomatic HIV Infection Who Have Failed or Are Intolerant to AZT Monotherapy, or Who Have Completed Other ddC Protocols, or Are Ineligible for Other Ongoing Clinical Studies

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

reference.citation: Adkins JC, Peters DH, Faulds D. Zalcitabine. An update of its pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic properties and clinical efficacy in the management of HIV infection. Drugs. 1997 Jun;53(6):1054-80. Review.
